p: Polysaccharides isolated from the leaves of C. odorata (L.) showed significant antioxidant and immunostimulatory activities via the stimulation of peripheral blood mononuclear cells and production of IFN-Î³ in a dose-dependent manner. Apart from polysaccharides, the plant also contains alkaloids, sterol, polyterpenes, and flavonoids which exhibited a wide range of therapeutic profile, such as wound healing, cytotoxic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant ( 146). Flavonoids present in the plant may transform the appearance of glucagon-like peptide 1 and its release via Takeda-G-protein-receptor-5, thereby showing antidiabetic activity ( 147).
